Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Flow Reactor Simulations of the Evolution of Atmospheric Organic Aerosol
Award.AbstractNarration:
The focus of this project is to investigate the yields of secondary organic aerosol (SOA) in an environmental chamber as a function of VOC/NOx levels and oxidant exposure. SOA formed from the OH oxidation of organic precursors happens mostly during the daytime. However, NO3 radicals are abundant at night. These elevated NO3 levels can also coincide with elevated levels of VOCs/IVOCs due to lower nighttime boundary layer heights, which may result in significant nighttime SOA formation. The chamber results will be used to model the underlying oxidation mechanisms and to relate them to atmospheric photochemical processes.

This research will provide new insight into the formation of secondary organic particles in the atmosphere and the oxidative aging of these particles. The results are important for understanding how aerosols influence the cooling and heating of the atmosphere and alter climate.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The aim of this project is to better understand the chemistry of organic aerosol (OA), fine particles in the Earth’s atmosphere which have major implications for global climate and human health but which remain poorly understood. In this work we used two reactors – an environmental chamber (involving low concentrations and long timescales) and a flow reactor (involving high concentrations and short timescales) – coupled with a range of state-of-the-art analytical instrumentation, in order to examine the chemistry that controls the amount and chemical composition of atmospheric OA. While the two types of reactors generally probe different equivalent atmospheric timescales (hours vs. days), there is some overlap between the two; in this overlapping region, the composition of OA from a given precursor was found to be not strongly dependent on the choice of reactor used, and amounts (yields) of aerosol varied only moderately (possibly due to differences in losses of compounds to the reactor walls). This general agreement in areas of overlap points to the complementarity of the two techniques for simulating OA chemistry over a range of atmospheric timescales. Additionally we carried out a series of organic “aging” experiments (involving relatively long timescales) in our environmental chamber, using a wide array of analytical instruments in order to trace the evolution of organic carbon over its first several days after emission. This work involved a greater amount of oxidation, and measurements of a wider range of organic compounds, than typically done in chamber studies. Importantly, we showed that after ~1 day of oxidation, most of the organic carbon had reacted to form either OA, or relatively unreactive (long-lived) gas-phase species such as CO, acetic acid, and acetone. Such results can be used to improve the chemistry within models that simulate the formation and evolution of atmospheric OA.
